Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Ultra Small-Angle X-ray Scattering Instrument for Multidisciplinary Materials Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: Manipulating and measuring the morphology of materials on multiple length scales has emerged as a key strategy for addressing the prominent technological problems confronting mankind today including grand challenges of affordable solar power, clean water, better designed medicines, and carbon sequestration. Access to equipment capable of investigating engineered materials systems on length scales from nanometers to micrometers is crucial, not only for scientific progress, but also for education and training. Such instruments of scientific discovery are necessary for both basic and applied research. These tools engender new skills in students, equipping the next generation with the skills necessary for rational materials design.


Technical: The complex problem of relating synthesis protocols and process variables to morphology and final properties is fundamental to materials research. It is most appropriately resolved by scattering techniques, which capture three-dimensional structural information (including bulk and buried structures) in reciprocal space. The goal of this project is to acquire an ultra-small-angle X-ray scattering (USAXS) instrument to investigate materials relevant to a range of multidisciplinary applications, including organic solar cells, passivating metallic films, nanostructured membranes, carbon nanotubes, nanoparticles and catalysts. The common theme in these research activities is the need to accurately explore hierarchical structure from the nano- to the meso-scale, since correlations between multiple length-scales give rise to unique functionalities that determine performance. The USAXS project meets this need by quantitatively probing critical length-scale domains, and complements existing resources such as wide-angle scattering, pinhole small-angle scattering, light scattering and x-ray reflectivity. The project thus transforms materials-related research at the University of Dayton and various other users in the south-west Ohio region (Miami University, Procter & Gamble, Environmental Protection Agency, Clopay Plastics) by providing scientists with quantitative structural data covering length scales from 5 nm to 1 micrometer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the most prominent scientific problems confronting mankind today are renewable energy, sustainability, and climate change. Indeed, the National Academy of Engineering has identified affordable solar power, clean water, better designed medicines and therapeutics, and carbon sequestration as some of the grand challenges of the twenty first century. These issues, as well as many others, are predicated upon understanding and exploiting the behavior of engineered materials, and on developing new materials with novel properties. Access to equipment capable of investigating these materials systems is crucial, not only for scientific progress, but also to advance education and training. Such instruments of scientific discovery enhance the capabilities of faculty and researchers in varied fields of academia and industry for both basic and applied research. These tools also engender new skills in students who constitute the next generation of scientists and engineers. Access to such advanced instrumentation thus also ensures that the workforce is uniquely equipped to enable rational materials design, and to address the challenges of the coming decades.

The complex problem of relating synthesis protocols and process variables to morphology and final properties is fundamental to materials research. One prominent approach to resolving this issue is via scattering techniques, which capture three-dimensional structural information (including bulk, thin-films, surface morphology, and internal structures) in reciprocal space.

This NSF-Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant funds, for the first time ever, the acquisition of an ultra-small-angle X-Ray scattering (USAXS) instrument to investigate materials relevant to a range of multidisciplinary applications, including organic solar cells, passivating metallic films, nanostructured membranes, carbon nanotubes, nanoparticles and catalysts. The common theme in these research activities is the need to accurately explore hierarchical structure from the nano- to the meso-scale, since correlations between multiple length-scales give rise to unique functionalities that determine performance. The USAXS instrument meets this need by quantitatively probing critical length-scale domains. The USAXS will transform materials-related research by providing scientists with quantitative structural data covering length scales from tens of nanometers to approximately 1 micrometer.  

The USAXS funded via this NSF-MRI grant is located in the Nanoscale Engineering Science and Technology (NEST) Laboratory, a user facility with numerous other materials characterization equipment located at the University of Dayton. The NEST lab, which is managed by the University of Dayton Research Institute (UDRI), attracts visitors from academia, industry and the government (Wright Patterson Air Force Base and Air Force Research laboratory), and is the most suitable channel for outreach and publicity regarding the USAXS and its capabilities.
